Today, these men, women & children have settled across the country – including in MI. There is still work to do securing permanent residency in the U.S & the status needed to fully contribute in America, but I am so proud of them & can’t wait to see the incredible things they do.

Getting those folks through the streets of Kabul, safely on a flight to Albania, & then finally to the U.S. was a long, meaningful saga. Seeing them finally step down on safe, American soil is an image I don’t think I will ever forget.

In March 2022, they landed in D.C., where myself, members of my staff, & representatives from @SpiritofAmerica & @MichiganStateU were waiting. At that moment, it was hard not to think of my own family, who had the same experience at Ellis Island so many years ago.

After much work with the White House & Homeland Security officials, the group – along with others that traveled to third party nations – were vetted to travel to the U.S. under Temporary Protected Status.

They were exhausted, worried about their families at home, & uncertain of what would happen to them. They asked me not to forget them, and as someone whose own family left their home in search of a better life, I assured them I would do everything I could to get them to the U.S.

@SpiritAmerica, an incredible non-profit organization, cared for the group in Albania while their U.S. visas were vetted and processed, and in November 2021 I traveled to Albania to meet them in person for the first time – one of the most moving experiences of my career.

Through an old friend, @amb_yurikim, we secured temporary safe harbor for the group in Albania – a nation that opened up its arms to welcome those who had nowhere else to go. Foreign Minister @xhacka_olta met them on the tarmac as they began the next chapter of their lives.

Their incredible odyssey was made possible through a network of good samaritans around the globe who contributed to the effort due to a shared obligation to help those who helped us in their time of greatest need.

Over the course of ten days, our group navigated an impossibly difficult environment – renting buses, moving through Taliban checkpoints in the dark, and dodging gunfire – finally making it through the gates at the airport and onto a plane that would bring them to safe harbor.

It’s been two years since a group of 114 Afghan nationals, many of them affiliated with @michiganstateu, landed in Albania after a harrowing escape from Afghanistan. Today, it remains one of the most meaningful things I’ve worked on as a Member of Congress:washingtonpost.com/national-…

Here in Congress, I’ll continue working to bring manufacturing back home, drive down costs & expand access for patients.

Then, last month, I hosted @SecBecerra in #MI07, where we talked directly with state hospital leaders about the shortage, its impact on Michiganders, and how it had shown once again how vital it is to maintain a sufficient supply of lifesaving drugs.

In June, I intro'd the Ensuring Access to Lifesaving Drugs Act, which would empower the FDA to cut red tape during shortages. I also intro'd the Increasing Prescription Drug Competition Act so more generics can have an easier path to come to market & ease supply issues.

After we first heard the alarm bells this summer, I joined my MI colleagues @SenGaryPeters & @SenStabenow to send a letter to the FDA asking the agency to do everything in its power to increase supplies of these critical drugs.

Republican leadership is bringing dozens of divisive amendments to the NDAA to the House floor – an extremist wish list. It’s the next step in their campaign to impose a nationwide ban on abortions. Today I went to the House floor to respond:
The NDAA is about paying our military and getting them what they need. Please keep your culture war baggage out of national security.
We need to hear what they are telling us and act accordingly. They are choosing politics over our women in uniform. They are choosing politics in the Senate over our national security.

They will not stop when states like Michigan organized to make sure we have protections for women who want abortions. They want every single American, starting with our service members, to live under the same rules that they choose in their states.

The authors of these amendments are from Alabama and Texas, which ban abortion including in cases of rape or incest. Why is this important? It's important because we need to hear what people are telling us. They are telling us that they will not stop with the reversal of Roe.

Last night, they chose culture wars over national security, and they're doing so as part of a clear effort to prevent every single American woman from accessing reproductive care. It is part and parcel of a larger campaign to impose a nationwide ban on abortion.

The NDAA funds our military, protects our national security, and has been a bipartisan priority for six decades. But overnight, Republican leadership decided to bring forward dozens of partisan amendments.

Top of the agenda: the ongoing shortage of lifesaving cancer drugs that has forced our hospitals in Michigan to ration care. This crisis has shown once again that maintaining a sufficient supply of pharmaceuticals is critical for not just patients, but for our national security.

The last 72 hours are the greatest indicator we have that Putin made a strategic mistake in Ukraine. We need to help the Ukrainians punch him in the mouth a few more times to change the status quo, so they can go to the negotiating table from a position of strength.

Putin invaded Ukraine because he thought he could wait us out — that our alliance’s resolve would waver. A year and a half later, he’s the one who’s wobbly. He’s the one who’s exposed, with serious problems in his ranks, because we’ve kept our coalition together to push him back.

U.S. posture at this stage should be watching events closely, assisting our Ukrainian allies in exploiting any battlefield opportunities, & staying flexible & alert at an unpredictable moment in history.

Last, while any challenge to Putin’s dictatorship is historic, we should remember: Prigozhin & Wagner are not good guys coming to liberate Russia & make it a blooming democracy. Remember, Prigozhin troll farms & influence operations targeted U.S. elections in 2016.

This isn’t just a problem for Putin inside Russia – it calls into question whether Russia can withstand Ukraine’s summer offensive. Wagner led some of the small military victories in Ukraine, so this is a chance for Ukraine’s forces to further liberate their land – stay tuned.

This would be the equivalent of the U.S. military depending on an armed defense contractor, & that contractor then turning on U.S. leadership & marching to D.C. The weakness of the once-formidable Russian military is stunning.

This is the clearest public confirmation of the folly of Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. And remember: Wagner, a private military force, was brought into Ukraine & put on the frontlines because of the failures of Russia’s regular military.

First, Russians fighting Russians on Russian soil, which we haven’t seen since the 1991 coup attempt, is born directly from Russia’s failures in Ukraine. Military forces with clear plans, chain of command, & operational success don’t devolve into violence against themselves.

While the government can’t fix most supply chain issues, it can contract with other companies to quickly produce these drugs; buy supplies from other nations; and deploy FDA teams to affected production facilities to swiftly bring them back online.

As someone whose mom died of ovarian cancer, I can’t imagine how the families whose loved ones’ treatment has been postponed due to drug shortages must feel. And while we hope the impacted drug manufacturer in India will soon be back online, there are emergency steps we can take.

I’m in contact with Michigan hospitals and the FDA to understand what emergency steps can be taken to address this crisis. I can’t imagine what I would have done if my mom was told she had to postpone her chemo treatments due to supply chain issues – this needs attention ASAP.

This is exactly why I founded the bipartisan Domestic Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Caucus: to bring production of these critical drugs back to the U.S. However, while there’s good work happening in the medium & long term on securing supply chains, this issue demands swift action.

The fundamental issue is that we are far too dependent on foreign sources for the ingredients used in our drugs. That’s why the shutdown of a factory in India due to quality and safety concerns leaves cancer patients in MI struggling to get the drugs needed for their treatment.

The ongoing shortage of cancer treatment drugs hits incredibly close to home for me – just like many of the patients waiting for their treatments today, my mom was treated for ovarian cancer. This crisis is just the latest consequence of a flawed pharmaceutical supply chain.

Fact: Gun violence is now the leading cause of death for American children. If the Speaker is serious about looking at the facts of mass shootings, he should start by signing on to my bill with @SenMarkey to fund CDC research into the root causes of gun violence.

These are good bills that take concrete action to make it harder to commit acts of violence with a gun. Our most basic responsibility as elected officials is to protect our communities & children, so I’m asking my colleagues to step up & do your duty to keep our kids safe.

The No Crime Left Behind Act would bar those who have been convicted of a misdemeanor involving a firearm from buying a gun for three years, so we can keep guns out of the hands of individuals who have proven they can’t handle them responsibly.

The Gun Violence Prevention Research Act would authorize $50 million per fiscal year over the next five years to boost the CDC’s firearms safety and gun violence prevention research, so that we can start studying gun violence and get the data we need to fight this epidemic.

The Safe Guns; Safe Kids Act – written based on the circumstances of the shooting at Oxford High School – would require parents to secure their firearms when a child is in the home and hold them responsible if the child uses the firearm to commit a crime.

The Pause for Gun Safety Act – written based on the circumstances of the shooting at MSU – would require a one-week waiting or “cooling off” period before a person may receive a firearm, so that they can’t use it in a fit of rage or crisis.

That system, girded by American leadership, isn’t perfect — but it’s the one that has kept us from major world wars for 70+ years.

I know that for some Americans this conflict has faded into the background, but for the sake of the Ukrainian people, our Allies in NATO, and the cost to the US, it’s critical that we continue to maintain the system we built at the end of WWII.

Last summer I traveled to Kyiv to meet with President Zelenskyy & see firsthand what the Ukrainians could do with the weapons we’ve provided. From holding the line outside Kyiv to reclaiming territory across the East, they’ve accomplished much, but there is still more to do.
So when the reflections begin on what we have spent in Ukraine, it is just as important to realize how much more in blood and treasure we would have had to spend if we had sat on our hands.
An unabated take over of Ukraine and aggression towards NATO could have started a spiral of escalation that could have led to American sons and daughters fighting a nuclear state.

Any action Putin could have taken to further threaten Europe could have triggered Article 5 consultations, setting NATO on a collision course with Russia and the very real possibility of outright war, with the U.S. expected to be the lead actor.

The nearby Baltic counties, NATO allies so physically close to Russia, would have rightly assumed that they could be next and could have called for the NATO alliance to formally prepare to defend them.

A failure to act would've been felt widely outside of Ukraine, with higher costs than what we have spent thus far — grain never would've been harvested or left Ukraine, causing an international food crisis, untenable inflation, and instability or state collapse in other places.
Putin would have likely tried to walk the streets of an occupied Kyiv to demonstrate success. Instead, today, President Biden was there honoring the sacrifice of the Ukrainian people.

Without security assistance and humanitarian aid, the Ukrainian economy would have been at risk of collapse, and the refugee crisis would have seen millions more in Europe and beyond, and without any hope of going home.
Without unity around sanctions, Russia would have significantly more money to resupply, train and purchase weapons, instead of relying on second-rate powers like Iran to supply their drone program.

But without outside support and unity, it’s fair to say it would have been much harder for them to turn back the tide of a nationwide invasion; a short war of attrition would have likely given way to occupation, and strong insurgency.

As we near the anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, it’s useful to take stock of where we are & where we could've been had the world not acted. Time & again, the Ukrainians have demonstrated a remarkable will to fight, which is just as important as arms or training. 1/
